definitions.definition: A fact or statement used to support a proposition ; a reason .

subdefinitions.definition: A series of propositions organized so that the final proposition is a conclusion which is intended to follow logically from the preceding propositions, which function as premises .

definitions.definition: An abstract or summary of the content of a literary work such as a book , a poem or a major section such as a chapter , included in the work before the content itself; ( figuratively ) the contents themselves.

examples: The neighbours got into an argument about the branches of the trees that extended over the fence.
Steve got in a physical argument with his neighbor and came away with a black eye.
While biking home, he got in an argument with the pavement.

definitions.definition: Any of the phrases that bear a syntactic connection to the verb of a clause .

subdefinitions.definition: The independent variable of a function .
The phase of a complex number .
A quantity on which the calculation of another quantity depends .
examples: The altitude is the argument of the refraction.

subdefinitions.definition: A value , or a reference to a value, passed to a function.
examples: Parameters are like labelled fillable blanks used to define a function whereas arguments are passed to a function when calling it, filling in those blanks.

subdefinitions.definition: A parameter at a function call ; an actual parameter , as opposed to a formal parameter .
A matter in question ; a business in hand .
The subject matter of an artistic representation , discourse , or writing ; a theme or topic .

definitions.definition: Evidence , proof ; ( countable ) an item of such evidence or proof.

main_definition: ( countable , also figuratively ) A fact or statement used to support a proposition ; a reason .
secondary_definitions: ( countable ) A process of reasoning ; argumentation .

( countable ) An abstract or summary of the content of a literary work such as a book , a poem or a major section such as a chapter , included in the work before the content itself; ( figuratively ) the contents themselves.
( countable ) A verbal dispute ; a quarrel .
( by extension , humorous or euphemistic ) Any dispute , altercation , or collision .
( countable , linguistics ) Any of the phrases that bear a syntactic connection to the verb of a clause .
( uncountable , archaic ) Evidence , proof ; ( countable ) an item of such evidence or proof.
